I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

 
1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to  the  People's  Republic  of  China  (PRC)  for  the  Shandong  Energy  Efficiency  and  Emission 
Reduction Project.1  
 
2. 
The aim of the project is to expand investment in energy efficiency in selected energy-
intensive  industries  in  Shandong  Province;  develop  energy  service  companies  (ESCOs);  and 
enhance  provincial  capacity  to  identify,  finance,  and  manage  similar  energy  efficiency  and 
emission reduction projects. 2 The project proposes to finance the investment through a financial 
intermediation loan (FIL).3 
 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

Rationale 

 
A. 
 
The  project  has  a  very  good  fit  and  direct  relevance  with  the  ongoing  and  targeted 
3. 
energy  intensity  reductions  in  the  PRC  to  meet  the  40%–45%  carbon  intensity4 reduction  by 
2020 compared to 2005. The project follows and complements a previous Asian Development 
Bank  (ADB)  loan  which  successfully  introduced  onlending  mechanism  to  finance  energy 
efficiency retrofits in a similar energy-intensive Guangdong Province.5 Shandong is the second 
largest, in terms of industrial outputs, among all provinces in the PRC. Accordingly, the industry 
sector  is  the  main  energy  consumer  in  Shandong  consuming  more  than  three-quarters  of  the 
total energy in 2010. Moreover, the energy supply in Shandong is heavily dependent on fossil 
fuels—coal  (71%)  and  oil  (26%)—causing  large  emissions.  The  province’s  total  energy 
consumption  in  2010  was  340  million  tons  of  standard  coal  equivalent  (tsce)—around  10%  of 
the national total. Shandong's gross domestic product (GDP) has grown consistently at a rapid 
rate,  expanding  from  CNY495.3  billion  in  1995  to  CNY3,941.6  billion  in  2010.  This  economic 
growth momentum in Shandong is expected to continue in the foreseeable future putting even 
greater emphasis on accelerating investments in energy efficiency.  
 
4. 
the  Eleventh  Five-Year  Plan,  2006–2010,  Shandong  Province's  energy 
consumption per CNY10,000 GDP declined by 22.09%.6 In 2010, its energy intensity7 improved 
to  1.025  tsce  per  CNY10,000  of  GDP.  Despite  improving  the  energy  intensity,  the 
underinvestment  in  energy  efficiency  and  the  existence  of many  energy-intensive  industries in 
the  province  provide  significant  opportunities  for  further  energy  intensity  reductions  through 
targeted investment.  
                                                 
1  A  project  preparatory  technical  assistance  was  approved  on  5  June  2009  for  $700,000.  ADB.  2009.  Technical 
Assistance to the People’s Republic of China for Preparing the Energy Efficiency and Emission Reduction Project 
in Shandong Province. Manila (TA 7295-PRC). 

During 

2  Examples of some of the energy-intensive industries that will be targeted by this project are iron and steel, cement, 

textile, and paper. 

3  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
4  Carbon  intensity  is  the  amount  of  carbon  by  weight  emitted  per  unit  of  energy  consumed.  It  is  also  commonly 

referred as greenhouse gas emissions per unit of GDP.  

5  ADB.  2008.  Report  and  Recommendation  of  the  President  to  the  Board  of  Directors:  Proposed  Multitranche 
Financing Facility and Administration of Grant for the People's Republic of China for Guangdong Energy Efficiency 
and  Environment  Improvement  Investment  Program.  Manila  (MFF  0020-PRC,  approved  on  4  June,  for 
$100,000,000). All three tranches utilizing the full loan amount ($100 million) have already been approved. 

6  Shandong  Provincial  Government  has  successfully  achieved  its  target  for  the  11th  plan  and  will  set  an  energy 

efficiency improvement target of 17% per unit of GDP by 2015. 

7   Energy intensity is a measure of the energy efficiency of a nation's economy. It is calculated as units of energy per 

unit of GDP. 

 2 
 

The  existing  industrial  energy  efficiency  financing  mechanisms  in  Shandong  benefit 
5. 
small  projects.  A  large  financing  gap  exists  for  medium-  and  large-sized  energy  efficiency 
projects that involve all or part of an industrial manufacturing process for an industry.8 Three key 
barriers  have  impeded  investment:  (i)  lack  of  familiarity  with  the  latest  energy  efficient 
technologies, combined with the enterprises’ perception of production interruptions and/or loss 
of  revenues;  (ii)  difficulties  for  commercial  banks  to  assess  cash  flow  benefits  and  forgo 
collateral for such investment projects which do not generate additional revenues; and (iii) lack 
of  capacity  for  evaluation  and  risk  assignments  for  energy  conservation  investments  by 
commercial  banks.  Limited  market-based  incentive  mechanisms  to  reward  investors  for 
reducing  emissions  through  energy  efficiency  also  discourage  investors.  These  market 
imperfections warrant targeted public interventions. 
 
Several measures have been adopted in designing this project to address these barriers 
6. 
(para. 5). Accordingly, the FIL modality was chosen to (i) allow multiple rollover of the ADB loan, 
thus, providing larger investments for energy efficiency over the loan tenor; (ii) build knowledge 
and capacity of provincial government and selected financial intermediary in evaluation and risk 
assignments  for  energy  efficiency  transactions;  (iii)  reduce  transaction  complexities  and  costs 
due  to  familiarity  and  experience  gained  by  the  project  management  office  (PMO)  and  the 
financial  intermediary  from  the  initial  subprojects;  and  (iv)  enhance  governance  and  improve 
safeguard compliance for energy efficiency investments beyond the first batch of subprojects.   
 
Consistent  with  the  Strategy  2020  goals, 9  the  project  encourages  private  sector 
7. 
investments. In the first batch, both selected subprojects are private enterprises. The emphasis 
on selecting innovative technologies in the selection of the first batch of subprojects is expected 
to  be  maintained  and  further  intensified  for  future  subprojects.  The  project  design  includes  an 
innovative  package  of  financial  incentives  and  rewards  (para.  21)  to  encourage  and  enhance 
participation from similar industrial enterprises,  thus, leveraging additional private investments. 
In  addition,  specific  recommendations  and  actions  are  also  being  finalized  under  the  TA 
(footnote  1)  to  facilitate  ESCO  participation  in  the  future  subprojects.  This,  combined  with  the 
recent  PRC  Circular  No.  25  of  the  National  Development  and  Reform  Commission  on  ESCO 
policy, will enhance engaging ESCO companies for the project.10  
 
The  selected  two  private  enterprises—Golden  Yimeng  Group  (Golden  Yimeng)  and 
8. 
Dongying  Lufang  Metallic  Materials  (Lufang)—are  both  industrial  leaders  in  their  respective 
areas and are proposing state-of-the-art energy efficiency and renewable energy technologies. 
The  Golden  Yimeng  subproject  includes  expanding  the  biogas  capturing  system  to  generate 
power  and  supply  heat,  using  biowaste  as  fuel  and  to  produce  organic  fertilizers,  waste  heat 
recovery  and  energy  conservation  from  various  process  units,  and  using  heat  from  solar 
parabolic  concentrators  to  supply  a  6-megawatt  steam  turbine  to  generate  electricity.  This  will 
be the first such large-scale industrial solar application in the PRC. Lufang is among the top six 
copper producers in the PRC. Lufang subproject will support and supplement the development 
of a zero coal copper ore smelting furnace—an innovative technology. This technology will set 
                                                 
8  The  size  of  an  energy  efficiency  investment  is  defined  by  the  estimated  investment  cost  of  a  single  energy 
efficiency technology intervention. The targeted energy efficiency investments of the proposed project range from 
$10  million  and  above,  compared  with  small-sized  investments  in  the  range  of  $1  million–$5  million  or  less.  The 
size of an industrial enterprise is defined by its annual revenues. According to the China State Statistical Bureau 
(2008  Guidelines),  enterprises  are  defined  as  medium-sized  if  their  annual  revenues  are  in  the  range  of  CNY30 
million to CNY300 million (approximately $4.4 million to $40 million), and large if in excess of CNY300 million. 

9  ADB.  2008.  Strategy  2020:  The  Long-Term  Strategic  Framework  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank,  2008–2020. 

10 Para.  11  of  Sector  Assessment  (Summary):  Energy  (accessible  from  the  list  of  linked  documents  in  Appendix  2) 

Manila. 

details on specifics of new ESCO policy. 

 3 

Impact and Outcome 

The  impact  of  the  project  will  be  reduced  industrial  energy  intensity  and  emissions  in 

the  new  market  entry  standard  for  future  copper  smelters  and  have  a  profound  impact  on 
energy efficiency and emission reduction efforts.11 
 
9. 
The  China  Everbright  Bank  (CEB),  Jinan  branch,  was  selected  as  the  financial 
intermediary through a competitive bidding process conducted in May 2010 (details on CEB are 
in paras. 29 and 30). The involvement of CEB, a commercial bank, in rolling over the fund will 
bring  in  sound  banking  expertise  and  governance  in  energy  efficiency  lending.  It  will  also 
strengthen  cooperation  between  the  government  agency  (the  PMO)  and  a  major  financial 
institution,  which  may  encourage  them  to  work  together  beyond  the  project  and  expand 
investments in this high priority area for the government. 
 
10. 
To ensure that high standards with regard to due diligence and assessment are followed 
beyond the first batch of subprojects, ADB, the Government of the PRC, Shandong Provincial 
Government (SPG), and CEB have agreed on a set of technical, financial, economic, social, and 
safeguards criteria  for  selecting  subborrowers  and  subprojects.12 This  will  assist  the PMO  and 
CEB in managing risks in future subprojects.   
 
B. 
 
11. 
Shandong Province. 
 
12. 
intensive industries of Shandong Province. 
 
C. 
 
13. 
The  outputs  will  be  (i)  priority  energy  efficiency  and  emission  reduction  projects 
implemented in selected energy-intensive industries; and (ii) capacity developed for government 
and  financial  institutions  in  planning,  investments,  and  management  of  energy  efficiency 
projects. 
 
D. 
 
14. 
The project investment cost, including estimated rollover of funds, is estimated at $553.2 
million,  of  which  $141.8  million  is  for  the  first  batch  of  subprojects.  The  total  cost  includes 
physical and price contingencies, and interest and other charges during development (Table 1).  
 
15. 
The  government  has  requested  financing  of  up  to  an  equivalent  of  $100  million  from 
ADB’s  ordinary  capital  resources  to  help  finance  selected  energy  efficiency  projects  using  the 
FIL  modality,  including  taxes  and  duties.13 Provisions  of  the  loan  regulations  applicable  to  the 
loan based on the London interbank offered rate (LIBOR) will apply.14 The loan will have a 15-
year  term  including  a  grace  period  of  10  years,  an  annual  interest  rate  determined  in 
accordance  with  ADB’s  LIBOR-based  lending  facility,  an  applicable  commitment  charge,  and 
such  other  terms  and  conditions  set  forth  in  the  draft  loan  and  project  agreements.  The 

The  outcome  of  the  project  will  be  expanded  energy  efficiency  investments  in  energy-

Investment and Financing Plans 

Outputs 

                                                 
11 Further details on these two projects are in the Innovative Energy Efficiency and Emission Reduction Technologies 

for the First Batch (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 

12 Subproject Selection Criteria and Loan Agreement (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
13 Goods and related transport and insurance costs will be financed by ADB loan. 
14 ADB. 2001. Ordinary Operations Loan Regulations Applicable to LIBOR-Based Loans Made from ADB's Ordinary 

Capital Resources. Manila. 

 

 4 
 

government has the option to choose between eligible currencies and the interest rate regime. 
The government has provided ADB with (i) the reasons for its decision to borrow under ADB’s 
LIBOR-based lending facility on the basis of these terms and conditions, and (ii) an undertaking 
that  these  choices  were  its  own  independent  decision  and  not  made  in  reliance  on  any 
communication  or  advice  from  ADB.  The  longer  grace  period  is  essential  to  maximize  the 
benefits of FIL so that the full amount of the loan is available for relending to a greater number 
of  industries  resulting  into  increased  energy  savings  and  emissions  reduction.  A  similar 
approach  was  adopted  for  the  Guangdong  Energy  Efficiency  and  Environment  Improvement 
Investment Program (footnote 5).

16. 
The  ADB  loan  will  be  onlent  to  selected  subprojects  through  CEB.  The  CEB  will 
establish a separate escrow revolving account (para. 20). For subsequent subprojects, CEB will 
onlend  the  repayment  proceeds  to  the  eligible  subborrowers  via  this  escrow  account. 15 
Financing for each subproject requires at least 25% equity from the respective sponsor or the 
subborrower.16  
 
17. 
Both selected subprojects, in the first batch, will have equity (29%) contributions from the 
sponsors  and  debt  financing  (71%)  from  ADB  loan.  For  future  subprojects,  it  is  expected  that 
commercial banks will provide debt financing together with the revolving fund. The $100 million 
FIL loan from ADB is expected to fully revolve about two times, supporting an additional eight 
batches of subprojects. Table 2 shows the tentative financing plan.

1.  Relending and Onlending Arrangements 

 
The PRC will be the borrower. The Ministry of Finance will relend the loan proceeds to 
18. 
SPG on the same terms and conditions as the loan between ADB and the PRC. SPG will make 
the  loan  proceeds  available  to  CEB,  under  the  terms  and  conditions  of  the  escrow  revolving 
account  management  agreement  for  further  onlending  to  selected  subborrowers  through 
subloan agreements between CEB and the subborrower. 
 

2. 

Specific Terms of the Financial Intermediation Loan Modality 

 
To  maximize  the  benefit  from  the  revolving  nature  of  the  financing,  the  term  of  each 
19. 
subloan will be no more than 6 years, including a grace period of 2 years. The loan repayment 
term  for  all  subprojects  will  match  the  payback  period  for  each  batch.  The  onlending  interest 
rate will be set within the allowable band of the rate permissible by the People’s Bank of China 
for a commercial loan but would be 10% lower than the existing prime rate of the same term.17 
The  Shandong  Provincial  Finance  Department  (SFD)  will  bear  the  risks  of  currency  exchange 
and interest rate fluctuations. Only subprojects satisfying the selection criteria (footnote 12) and 
technically  appraised  by  the  PMO  with  the  assistance  of  CEB  will  be  financed  for  subsequent 
batches. 
 
20. 
To  ensure  that  ADB  loan  proceeds,  as  well  as  interest  payments  and  principal 
repayments from the subborrowers are not commingled with the other funds being administered 
by CEB, a separate escrow revolving account will be established and maintained by CEB for all 
transactions  related  to  the  project  and  administration  of  the  FIL.  This  will  ensure  that  the 
account is kept distinct from CEB’s own assets and provide protection against adverse results 
from  other  CEB  financial  operations.  Since  the  loan  proceeds  will  not  be  relent  to  CEB,  the 
requirement  to  relend  ADB  proceeds  to  a  financial  intermediary  on  terms  no  more  favorable 
than  ordinary  capital  resources  terms  is  not  applicable.  Rather  than  relending  the  loan 
proceeds, the funds will be made available to CEB under an escrow arrangement between SFD 
and CEB. 
 
SFD  will  establish  a  Shandong  energy  efficiency  and  emission  reduction  account  to 
21. 
provide  support  for  the  project.  The  account  will  be  principally  funded  from  the  interest 
differential  between  the  FIL  onlending  rate  to  the  subborrowers  and  ADB’s  interest  rate 

                                                 
17  The interest rates of the local commercial banks in the PRC are regulated based on a prime rate declared by the 
People’s  Bank  of  China.  However,  the  interest  rates  on  individual  transactions  are  allowed  to  deviate  from  the 
prime rate within a narrow band to reflect the credit risk of the borrower. The current prime rate in the PRC for the 
same tenor of the subloan is 6.80%. With the 10% discount, the interest rate on the subloan will be about 6.12%. 
The interest differential on the subloan will, therefore, be about 3.39%, if the equivalent fixed interest swap rate on 
the ADB loan is considered. 

 

 6 
 

(footnote  17).18 The  account  will  be  principally  rebated  to  the  subborrowers  who  achieve  the 
targeted energy savings, subject to monitoring and verification by independent consultants. 
 
SFD  will  pay  for  the  financial  intermediary  management  fees  (approximately  0.2%  per 
22. 
annum  of  the  ADB  loan  amount),  and  PMO  administration  costs  including  procurement  of 
independent  consultants  for  professional  services  based  on  the  actual  amount.  These 
professional services will include (i) appraisal and selection of future subprojects; (ii) subproject 
capacity  building,  where  appropriate;  (iii)  implementation  of  ADB  monitoring  and  reporting 
requirements  for  the  project;  (iv)  subproject  performance  tracking  and  verification  in  terms  of 
energy  savings  and  emission  reductions;  and  (v)  production  of  an  operations  manual  as  a 
reference  point  for  future  energy  efficiency  investments  in  order  to  replicate  the  experience 
gained  by  the  PMO  and  financial  intermediary.  To  meet  these  critical needs,  a  separate  PMO 
account will be opened in accordance with SFD’s procedure.  
 

Implementation Arrangements 

The  implementation  arrangements  summarized  in  Table  3  are  for  the  first  batch  of 

E. 
 
23. 
subprojects. Further details are in the project administration manual (PAM).19  
 
CEB will (i) conduct financial due diligence and creditworthiness of new subprojects; (ii) 
24. 
make  suitable  recommendations  to  the  PMO  on  subproject  applications  based  on  its  financial 
assessments;  (iii)  provide  cofinancing,  if  appropriate;  (iv)  manage  disbursement,  interest 
payment,  and  principal  collection  processes;  and  administer  the  subloan  portfolio;  (v)  manage 
counterguarantees, securitization, and collateral issues; (vi) manage exchanges of foreign and 
domestic currencies; (vii) ensure yearly audits of accounts; (viii) take necessary actions against 
nonperforming loans; and (ix) provide monthly reports to the PMO.20 SFD will make lending and 
pricing decisions, and bear the credit risk of the subproject.

Arrangements 

 

2011–2016 
 
19 September 2016 
 
Project Leading Group 
Members:  SFD,  Shandong  Provincial  Development  and  Reform  Commission, 
Shandong  Provincial  Economic  and  Information  Technology  Commission,  and 
Shandong Environment Protection Department. 
Shandong Provincial Government  
The  Shandong  Provincial  Government  has  established  the  PMO  to  implement  the 
project.a  The  PMO  will  (i)  solicit  energy  efficiency  and  emission  reduction 
subprojects;  (ii)  review  and  assess  subproject  applications  according  to  the 
selection  criteria  and  approval  process  for  subprojects;  (iii)  decide  on  subproject 
applications  with  help 
the 
implementation  of  subprojects;  (v)  ensure  environmental  and  social  safeguard 
compliance  through  implementation  of  the  environmental  and  social  management 
system;  (vi)  measure  and  verify  energy  savings  and  emission  reduction  of 
completed  subprojects;  and  (vii)  monitor  and  manage  the  project,  and  produce 
quarterly  reports  for  the  project  to  be  submitted  to  ADB  in  accordance  with  the 

(iv)  oversee

 Aspects 

(iv) 
Procurement 

project administration manual as agreed by ADB and the government. 
Implementation unit  180 Quancheng Road, Jinan, Shandong, five staff from project PMO. 

Arrangements 

7 

Procurement will be done in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, 
as amended from time to time). Subborrowers will be required to follow the relevant 
procurement  rules  in  ADB’s  Procurement  Guidelines  for  financial  intermediaries, 
and  adopt  appropriate  procedures  including  (i)  payment  of  reasonable  prices,  and 
(ii)  fair  canvassing  when  selecting  suppliers.  Procurement  must  be  from  ADB 
member  countries.  Subborrowers  will  be  encouraged  to  procure  goods  through 
competitive bidding or shopping when such procedures are most appropriate in the 
interest  of  economy  and  efficiency.  A  procurement  manual  indicating  the  detailed 
procurement  procedure  that  will  be  used  under  the  overall  project  implementation 
will  be  prepared  by  the  PMO  before  procurement  activities  are  undertaken,  and 
submitted  to  ADB  for  review  and  approval.  In  case  of  noncompliance,  CEB  will 
exercise the right to recall the subloan. 
Both  subborrowers  have  requested  advanced  contracting  and  retroactive  financing 
up  to  20%  under  each  subloan.  A  total  of  six  procurement  packages  are  under 
advanced  contracting.  Retroactive  financing  up  to  20%  is  allowed,  provided  such 
expenses are incurred in accordance with procurement practices acceptable to ADB 
and  not  more  than  12  months  before  the  signing  of  the  loan  agreement.  The 
government  has  been  informed  that  provision  of  advance  contracting  and 
procurement  and  retroactive  financing  does  not  commit  ADB  to  financing  the 
subprojects.

Special disbursement 
arrangement for the escrow 
revolving account 
SAW procedure

The  loan  proceeds  will  be  withdrawn  from  SFD’s 
account and transferred to CEB’s escrow revolving 
account following necessary domestic procedures. 
SAW procedures will be used for subloans up to a 
free  limit  of  $15  million.  Subloans  exceeding  the 
free limit will require ADB’s prior approval.

III. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

Economic and Financial 

 
The  project  incorporates  lessons 21  from  an  earlier  energy  efficiency  and  emission 
25. 
reduction  project  in  Guangdong  Province  regarding  design,  preparation,  risk  assessment  and 
management, and implementation arrangements. Results of financial due diligence assessment 
of the first batch of subborrowers are shown in Appendix 2.22  
 
A. 
 
26. 
Financial  analysis.  The  financial  internal  rate  of  return  is  calculated  for  each  of  the 
subprojects in the first batch as well as for both the subprojects combined which are 23.3% for 
Golden Yimeng, 22.4% for Lufang, and 22.9% for the two subprojects, respectively. Sensitivity 
analysis  shows  that  the  subprojects  are  financially  viable  under  various  adverse  scenarios.23 
The  financial  analysis  for  the  first  set  of  subprojects  is  assumed  to  be  representative  of  the 
whole  FIL  project.  Specific  financial  criteria  (footnote  12)  are  formulated  for  future  batches  of 

                                                 
21 Para.  15  of  Sector  Assessment  (Summary):  Energy  (accessible  from  the  list  of  linked  documents  in  Appendix  2) 

indicates the main lesson learned from Guangdong project.  

22 Financial Performance and Projections of Subproject Companies (accessible from the  list of linked  documents in 

Appendix 2). 

23 Financial Analysis (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 

 

 

 8 
 

Governance 

subprojects  to  ensure  financial  viability  and  sustainability.  The  financial  intermediary,  who  will 
oversee such assessments, will follow ADB guidelines. 
  
27. 
Economic  analysis.  The  economic  internal  rate  of  return  including  environmental 
benefits  is  calculated  for  each  of  the  subprojects  in  the  first  batch  as  well  as  for  both  the 
subprojects  combined  which  are  37.3%  for  Golden  Yimeng,  39.0%  for  Lufang,  and  38.2%  for 
both  subprojects  combined,  respectively.24 Without  environmental  benefits,  the  internal  rate  of 
return  for  Golden  Yimeng  is  27.6%,  Lufang  36.0%,  and  both  projects  combined  32.7%.  The 
sensitivity  analysis  under  various  adverse  scenarios  shows  the  economic  viability  of  both 
projects. 
 
B. 
 
28. 
Policy  and  regulatory  risks  are  minimal  and  the  benefits  from  the  project  will  ensue  as 
the government and SPG are expected to maintain priority for energy intensity in line with the 
government’s commitment up to 2020 (para. 3) and recent ESCO policy (para. 7).  
 
A  due  diligence  assessment  was  conducted  for  CEB,25 which  is  a  national  commercial 
29. 
bank established in 1992. In 2009, CEB was on the list of the 16 best banks of Asia, and is one 
of the top 10 banks of the PRC. ADB was a shareholder and board member of CEB from 1996 
to 2007. During that period, ADB provided a technical assistance26 and a loan27 to enhance the 
capacity  of  CEB  in  prudent  banking  practices  and  successfully  introduced  international  best 
practices  to  CEB,  particularly  in  credit  appraisal,  post  disbursement  loan  management,  and 
corporate  governance,  which  have  also  benefited  the  CEB  Jinan  branch.  The  CEB  Jinan 
branch,  in  Shandong  Province,  is  a  major  onlender  of  loans  from  foreign  governments  and  
international financial institutions,28 and is familiar with the policies and procedures of SFD. 
 
30. 
By  the  end  of  2009,  CEB's  total  assets  reached  CNY1.198  trillion,  with  a  total  loan 
portfolio  of  CNY632  billion.  At  the  end  of  2009,  CEB  generated  an  operating  income  of 
CNY24.26 billion, with a net profit of CNY7.64 billion, an increase of 34.8% after excluding the 
tax  preference  factor  of  the  previous  year.  Return  on  equity  was  19.43%  in  2009.  CEB  has  a 
registered  capital  of  CNY33.43  billion.  After  the  initial  public  offering  in  August  2010,  Central 
Huijin Investment (China SAFE Investment) continues to be the single largest shareholder with 
a 49.61% stake.  
 
31. 
ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with  the  government,  SPG,  the  financial  intermediary,  and  subborrowers.  The  specific  policy 
requirements and supplementary measures are described in the PAM.

 9 

Safeguards 

Poverty and Social  

C. 
 
32. 
The  project  will  have  a  positive  social  impact  by  reducing  air  pollution  associated  with 
coal use. Thus, it will result in reducing respiratory diseases among residents in the project area. 
However,  the  project  will  not  result  in  any  direct  benefits  to  low-income  households  and 
communities  by  reducing  poverty.  The  project  may  provide  some  benefits  to  both  men  and 
women  in  employment  opportunities  during  construction  and  operation,  and  appropriate  loan 
covenants on compliance with national labor laws are included. 
 
D. 
 
33. 
involuntary 
resettlement, and indigenous peoples categorizations. Accordingly, an environmental and social 
management  system  (ESMS)  document  will  be  prepared  based  on  the  agreed  ESMS 
arrangement29 with SPG and made available for review before the first disbursement. SPG will 
update the ESMS document as needed, and submit it to ADB as per ESMS requirements. The 
selection criteria specify that subprojects will not involve land acquisition and resettlement, and 
will not have any adverse impact on any ethnic minority group; this is stipulated in the project 
agreement.  Environmental  benefits  including  potential  for  energy  efficiency  improvements  and 
greenhouse  gas  emission  reductions  (Table  4)  deriving  from  the  subprojects  can  potentially 
become eligible for the Clean Development Mechanism.

Mitigating Measures 
The  initial  first  batch  of  subprojects  is  ready  for  implementation.  They  already  have 
feasibility  study  report  and  environment  impact  assessment  approval  and  counterpart 
funding  in  place.  Advance  contracting  and  retroactive  financing  will  support  timely

and 

The  financial  intermediary  capacity  was  thoroughly  assessed.  Being  a  large  publicly 
listed commercial bank, it has required capacity and system and procedures in place to 
perform satisfactorily. The project management office capacity was strengthened under 
the project preparatory technical assistance and experience from a similar World Bank 
loan.  To  ensure  availability  of  adequate  resources,  Shandong  Provincial  Finance 
Department  will  establish  a  fund  to  pay  for  project  management  office  administration, 
capacity building, and hiring of implementation consultants.

E. 
 
34. 

 

 10 

IV. 

ASSURANCES AND CONDITIONS 

 
35. 
The  government  and  SPG  have  assured  ADB  that  implementation  of  the  project  shall 
conform  to  all  applicable  ADB  policies  including  those  concerning  anticorruption  measures, 
safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in detail 
in the PAM and loan documents. Further, the government and SPG have agreed with ADB on 
certain covenants for the project, which are set forth in the loan and project agreements. 
 
The government and SPG have agreed that the loan will be declared effective only when 
36. 
escrow  account  management  agreement,  in  form  and  substance  satisfactory  to  ADB,  is 
executed and delivered on behalf of SFD and CEB and has become fully effective and binding 
upon SFD and CEB in accordance with its terms. 
 
37. 
The government and SPG have agreed that no withdrawals will be made from the loan 
account, in respect of any subproject, until the following conditions are met: (i) SFD has certified 
to  ADB  that  the  subloan  agreement  related  to  any  such  subproject,  including  the  terms  and 
conditions satisfactory to ADB, have been duly executed and delivered on behalf of CEB, SFD 
acting  on  behalf  of  SPG,  and  the  subborrower,  and  have  become  fully  effective  and  binding 
upon the parties thereto in accordance with their terms; and (ii) SPG has certified to ADB that 
the ESMS for the project, as prepared by the PMO and approved by ADB, has been endorsed 
and adopted by the PMO. 
 

V. 

RECOMMENDATION 

 
I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
38. 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and  recommend  that  the  Board  approve  the  loan  of 
$100,000,000  to  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  for  the  Shandong  Energy  Efficiency  and 
Emission  Reduction  Project  from  ADB’s  ordinary  capital  resources,  with  interest  to  be 
determined  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  London  interbank  offered  rate  (LIBOR)-based  lending 
facility; for a term of 15 years, including a grace period of 10 years; and such other terms and 
conditions  as  are  substantially  in  accordance  with  those  set  forth  in  the  draft  loan  and  project 
agreements presented to the Board. 

 
 
 
Haruhiko Kuroda 
President 
 
 
 

26 July 2011

Activities with Milestones 
 
Activity 1: Investment in priority energy efficiency and emission reduction subprojects  
1.1  The first batch of energy efficiency subprojects are implemented in energy-intensive 

industrial enterprises through a financial intermediary (2012–2016). 

1.2  The  financial  intermediary  model,  set  of  criteria,  and  relevant  procedures  including 
the  environmental  and  social  management  system  are  in  place  to  support  future 
projects in Shandong Province (2012). 

1.3  The  PMO  and  financial  intermediary  are  setup  to  (i)  screen  potential  investment 
subprojects  for  future  support  from  the  FIL,  (ii)  implement  a  performance  and 
monitoring system for the subprojects under implementation, and (iii) report results to 
ADB (2012–2016).  
 

Activity 2: Capacity strengthened in energy efficiency management  

2.1  The  PMO  and  financial  intermediary  capacity  strengthened  through  hands-on 
involvement  in  financing  and  monitoring  priority  energy  efficiency  and  emission 
reduction projects (2012–2020).
